node.text: You are perched on a great mantlepiece that drops precipitously to a floor you can not see. You are not alone.

Out of the shadows emerges an winged insect. Ornate antennae dangle in in front of its face, most of which is taken up by massive compound eyes and complex looking mouth parts. Silken fur covers its hard exoskeleton. Stationary it might look pretty, but it moves its six legs with the clumsiness of a toddler.
The insect-beast stares at you and clicks its mouth-parts.
The insect-beast stares at you and clicks its mouth-parts.

response.text: "Why are you clicking your mouth parts incessantly?"

node.text: The complex mouth parts move, and in a dry, hissing voice it speaks: "Hi"
The complex mouth parts move, and in a dry, hissing voice it speaks: "That's a complicated question. I am a moth. But I used to be something else. Like you."

response.text: "Great. How do I stop being a moth?"

node.text: The complex mouth parts move, and in a dry, hissing voice it speaks: "None of us know."

As you speak those words you realise you have the same insecty voice as the moth in front of you. You look down and see segmented legs full of inhuman angles. As your eyes adjust to the darkness you also realise you can only see in black and white. You become aware of muscles and joints you never had before. It appears that you are, in fact, a moth.

response.text: "Interesting. I don't like it. How do I stop being a moth?"

node.text: "I saw some of the other moths doing it. I think its a way of showing reassurance"
"There must be some way. Maybe if you explore you can find a way. The only useful information I can give you is that behind the clock is a spool of thread. Perhaps other moths know clues as well."

secret.text: There is a spool of thread behind the clock!

node.text: "I don't know. All I know is that those who eat the rotten fruit become more moth-like with every bite. Those who have been here the longest you can't even talk to, they have forgotten human language. But eat it we must. There's no other food. And it's so ... delicious."

response.text: I hope I find a way out ...

node.text: At the end of the mantlepiece is an unlit oil lamp. Within the glass vessel a moth frantically tries to fly, but is unable to escape. Outsidereact, another moth looks on in despair
The moth outside spins round. "Oh! I ... am new here. I can't remember my name. I think I used to be a firefighter. But you have to help me!"
"My friend is stuck in the oil lamp! I think she was my friend. We ... arrived here together. You have to help!"
"What? I don't know ... it just happened. Everything just happens. "
"She was trying to get the note from inside the lamp." As you look closer you see that there is indeed a piece of paper with untidy writing scrawled on it. Its edges are burnt, barely.
"Her wings are injured. I tried to fly in and carry her out, but couldn't. I guess moth wings aren't strong enough for two."
You come across a moth awkwardly flapping it's wings along to some unheard beat

response.text: [Say Nothing, and flap your wings too]

node.text: "Oh hello. No. I can't, but there was a song I knew ... once ... If I could only remember how it went, i would be so happy!"

response.text: "Fret not! I shall find you this mystery song!"

node.text: After a while the moth notices you, and gets excited: "You know the song too! Do you know its name?! I have spent weeks trying to " remember it ... "
The moth goes back to flapping its wings.
"Oh... I hope some day I find it ..."
